The Caucasus subregion is a land bridge between the Black and 
Caspian seas. It is the shortest transit link to connect Central Asia 
to  Europe,  the  Russian  Federation,  and  Turkey.  The  subregion 
once served caravans from the People’s Republic of China to the 
West along the historic Silk Road, but is now a conduit for oil and 
other  exports  from  Central  Asia  and  the  Caucasus.  Yet,  despite 
the substantial transit potential, opportunities for this are affected 
by  the  degraded  state  of  basic  transport  infrastructure  and 
logistics services.  
 
The  east–west  highway  between  Azerbaijan  and  Georgia  is 
already a major route for oil exports from Azerbaijan and Central 
Asian  countries,  in  both  cases  relying  on  the  ports  of  Poti  and 
Batumi  on  the  Black  Sea  as  the  exit  points.    Another  corridor 
further south also uses these ports, but this time it services trade 
flows to and from Armenia.  This second corridor links the Agrak–

In  2008,  the  Government  of  Georgia  endorsed  a  joint  needs 
assessment  (JNA)  prepared  by  the  United  Nations  together  with  
ADB,  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development, 
European  Commission,  European  Investment  Bank,  International

the  World  Bank.  The  JNA 
recommended investments in the country's road networks, noting 
its  poor  state  of  repair  and  the  negative  impact  on  the  cost  of 
doing  business  and  foreign  direct  investment.    The  JNA  also 
emphasized  the  need  for  subregional  multi-road  corridors  to 
provide  more  secure  and  effective  transit  routes  to  neighboring 
countries.    In  2009,  the  Roads  Department  under  the  Ministry  of 
Regional  Development  and  Infrastructure  updated  the  road 
transport

urgent  modernization,  upgrading,  expansion  and/or  rehabilitation. 
The  investment  program  also  included  non-physical  components 
such  as  (i)  better  sector  policy  and  operating  procedures;  (ii) 
private  sector  participation  in  construction  and  maintenance;  and 
(iii)  the  development  of  capacity  to  improve  planning,  project 
management,  monitoring,  evaluation,  and  reporting.  The  overall 
investment  plan  is  estimated  at  $3  billion  over  the  next  7 years. 
This plan needs external financing. The Government has already 
approached  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  the  Millennium  Challenge 
Corporation, and the Japan International Cooperation Agency for 
assistance.  
 
Tranche 1 of this investment program has four components: (i) the 
construction  of  a  34  km  two-lane  bypass  skirting  Kobuleti, 
(ii) capacity assistance to the Roads Department; (iii) road safety 
measures and (iv) project management support, including experts 
to work on detailed works design and contractor supervision. 
 
The Government requested ADB to extend up to $500 million for 
the  program  through  an  MFF.  This  financing  will  blend  ADB’s 
ordinary  capital  resources  (OCR)  and  Special  Funds  resources, 
depending on availability. The MFF will be structured into several 
loans to be disbursed on the basis of periodic financing requests 
(PFRs),  related  loan  agreements  and  various  warranties  and 
representations.  The  MFF  modality  offers  greater  flexibility  than 
other modalities, frontloads the analytical work and leaves for time 
and resources for implementation and reforms.  The modality links 
project  readiness  to  investment  financing  and  combines  road 
construction work with institutional effectiveness. It adds certainty 
to  the  financing  plan  while  paving  the  way  for  long  term 
partnerships with the government and other cofinanciers.  Stand-
alone  project  loans,  traditional  program  lending,  sector  lending 
and/or development program loans are less suitable modalities in 
this instance.  Georgia meets all the conditions needed for the use 
of an MFF. It has sound road map for the sector, a strong policy

Connectivity,  both  domestic  and  international,  is  the  key  to 
sustainable  development  in  Georgia.  However,  rapid  growth  in 
traffic up to 2008 and lack of investment since independence have 
greatly  diminished  the  efficiency  of  the  subregional  corridors. 
Growth  and  poverty  reduction  have  stalled,  as  a  result.  The 
corridors  must  increase  their  capacity,  through  new  investment 
and  better  maintenance.  Improved  road  safety  measures  and 
standards,  and  “soft”  investments  to  facilitate  cross-border  trade 
and transit traffic, are also needed.

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 The Caucasus subregion is a land bridge between the Black Sea and the Caspian Sea. 
2. 
It  is  the  shortest  transit  link  to  connect  Central  Asia  to  Europe,  the  Russian  Federation,  and 
Turkey. The subregion once served caravans from the People’s Republic of China to the West 
along the historic Silk Road, but is now a conduit for oil and other exports from Central Asia and 
the Caucasus. Yet, despite the substantial transit potential, opportunities for this are affected by 
the degraded state of basic transport infrastructure and logistics services.  
 
3. 
The east–west highway between Azerbaijan and Georgia is already a major route for oil 
exports from Azerbaijan and Central Asian countries, in both cases relying on the ports of Poti 
and Batumi on the Black Sea as the exit points.  Another corridor further south also uses these 
ports, but this time it services trade flows to and from Armenia.  This second corridor links the 
Agrak–Kapan–Yerevan–Bavra road in Armenia with two southern sections in Georgia. 

1. 

Road Infrastructure and Motor Fleet 

4. 
The transport network in Georgia consists comprises roads, railways, ports, airports, and 
oil  and  gas  pipelines.  Road  transport  accounted  for  89%  of  domestic  passenger-kilometers

5. 
The road network comprises 20,329 km. There are 1,495 km of international roads (with

Road Transport Service 

Georgia’s road freight industry is made up of private companies but is unregulated. Entry 
8.

km  come  with  highly  competitive  market  prices.  Intercity  bus  services  are  extensive  and

passengers pay around GEL18. Limited stops and comfortable premium services would change 
the intercity transport market considerably. Bus ridership would very likely increase.

1. 

Challenges 

Like other sectors in Georgia, the road subsector has been transformed from a centrally 
11. 
planned  to  a  market-oriented  system  since  independence.  The  subsector  faces  four  major 
challenges:  (i)  inadequate  capacity  of  the  road  network,  including  subregional  corridors,  (ii) 
insufficient  funding  for  capital  investment  and  road  maintenance,  (iii)  unsatisfactory  safety 
record, and (iv) limited institutional capacity. 
 
12. 
Road  network  infrastructure.  Georgia’s  road  network  is  a  crucial  component  of 
national and subregional transport and trade infrastructure. The east–west highway is part of the 
Asian  highway  network  connecting  Georgia  and  Turkey  to  Azerbaijan  and  Central  Asia.1 The 
southern  corridor  connects  the  country  to  Armenia.    Georgia  is  a  signatory  to  several 
international  transport  agreements  and  conventions.  The  continued  development  of  an 
integrated  and  efficient  road  network  facilitates  cross-border  and  transit  traffic  and  promotes 
subregional cooperation and integration. The existing road network does not adequately serve 
the current needs of the economy and the subregion, and many roads are still in poor condition. 
Funding  for  capital  investment  and  the  maintenance  of  secondary  and  local  roads  is  still 
inadequate.  A  large  part  of  the  network  has  deteriorated  rapidly  since  the  1990s  and  is  now 
hard to maintain. The resulting increase in transport costs and in traffic accidents has impeded 
faster  growth  and  makes  poverty  reduction  more  difficult.  The  road  subsector  must  be 
developed to facilitate subregional trade, jobs, investment, and tourism.

Road safety. Road safety needs serious attention; there has been a sharp rise in traffic 
accidents,  fatalities,  and  injuries.  The  current  fatality  rate  is  much  higher  than  in  European 
countries,  and  the  economic  and  human  losses  have  been  significant.  While  traffic  accidents 
have  many  causes,  the  inadequate  road  network  is  a  factor.  Curves  and  superelevation  are 
inappropriately  designed  on  many  roads,  and  safety  furniture  is  lacking.  Other  causes  of 
accidents  are  weak  enforcement  of  safety  regulations,  reckless  driving,  and  a  larger  vehicle 
fleet.  The  Government  needs  to  take  remedial  action  to  curb  accidents.  The  more  than  6,000 
accidents  in  2008  that  involved  death  or  serious  injury  and  killed  867  people  represented  an 
increase of more than 18% over the 2007 figure. The fatality rate relative to the vehicle fleet, at 
12  per  10,000  vehicles  in  2008,  is  high  (removing  scrapped  vehicles  from  the  fleet  statistics 
would result in an even-higher rate)—and exceeds the rate in other European countries.2 Both 
fatalities  and  serious  injuries  are  on  the  rise.  Road  safety  has  thus  become  a  social  concern. 
The Government developed the National Traffic Safety Strategy in 2008 and is now  making a 
bigger effort to strengthen law enforcement and launching public campaigns for road safety. 
 
15. 
Institutional  capacity.  Despite  recent  progress  in  the  reform  of  institutions,  the  road 
subsector still has limited institutional capacity. The limitations are reflected in (i) still weak legal 
and  regulatory  framework  for  managing  the  road  network;  (ii)  limited  enforcement  of  some 
regulations,  such  as  those  relating  to  vehicle  axle-load  controls  and  road  safety;  (iii) lack  of 
experience  in  and  knowledge  of  public–private  partnerships  for  road  construction  and 
maintenance;  and  (iv)  limited  staff  experience  in  managing  road  projects,  particularly  where 
tunnel and bridge engineering and environmental and resettlement safeguards are concerned. 
Although some donors have being supporting institutional strengthening, the Roads Department 
needs more assistance, ideally within the context of the proposed investment program.

Lessons  

21. 
ADB operations in Georgia are just starting. Thus, there are no substantive lessons from 
previous projects. But operations by other partners do provide hints on risks.  First, each project 
to  be  financed  under  the  MFF  needs  an  in-depth  assessment  of  its  technical,  economic, 
environmental,  and  social  aspects  (including  land  acquisition  and  resettlement)  to  establish

messages.    One  lesson  learned  from  other  countries  is  the  importance  of  establishing  sound 
cross-border arrangements to cut travel time schedules and costs.

THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

 
A. 

Impact and Outcome 

The investment program will promote economic development and subregional trade, and 
24. 
accelerate  subregional  cooperation  and  integration.  It  will  create  better  trade  and  logistic 
corridors, and facilitate the cross-border movement of people and cargo. The outcome will be an 
improved subregional road network. The successful implementation of the investment program 
will (i) improve the efficiency of subregional road traffic through Georgia; (ii) increase trade flows 
and  competitiveness;  (iii)  lower  transport  costs;  (iv)  increase  mobility  and  access  to  markets, 
jobs, and social services; and (v) improve governance. 

B. 

Outputs 

25. 
The outputs will be (i) roads  improved in the subregional road network, (ii) effective and 
efficient  management  of  the  road  network,  and  (iii)  improved  road  safety.  For  the  road 
infrastructure component, priority roads will be built, upgraded, or rehabilitated. The selection of 
roads to be financed under the MFF will be based on the updated JNA and economic, social, 
environmental,  and  technical  assessments.  (The  selection  criteria  and  approval  process  for 
projects  and  subprojects  to  be  financed  under  the  MFF  are  in  Appendix  5.)  The  management 
capacity  component  will  be  concerned  with  master  planning  for  the  road  subsector,  axle-load 
control,  private  sector  participation  in  road  construction  and  maintenance,  and  the  design  and 
construction  of  tunnels  and  bridges.  The  road  safety  component  will  address  sustained  safety 
training, the adoption of intelligent traffic system technologies, the amendment of regulations to 
incorporate rules for high-speed transport and for tunnel safety, and the development of national 
standards for intelligent traffic systems.

A. 

Benefits 

52. 
The  investment  program  will  benefit  road  users,  road  construction  companies,  traders, 
logistics companies, and other people who derive income from increased road traffic and trade 
in  Georgia.  Regarding  direct  benefits,  the  improved  road  network  will  (i)  lower  road  transport 
and  maintenance  costs,  (ii)  speed  up  road  transport  services  and  make  them  more  reliable, 
(iii) reduce  travel  time  for  cross-border  transit  traffic,  (iv)  reduce  traffic  accidents,  (v)  improve 
access  to  markets  and  social  services,  (vi)  create  jobs  and  income  during  implementation 
(through  the  use  of  local  labor  and  construction  materials)  and  after  completion  (through 
roadside business activities), and (vii) reduce air pollution and noise in resort areas where the 
existing road passes. The direct benefits will accrue at the start to vehicle owners and operators 
and  road  construction  companies,  but  will  gradually  be  shared  by  freight  customers  and 
passengers  through  reduced  bus  freight  charges  and  fares.  While  Georgia  is  the  major 
beneficiary, other countries in the region, particularly Armenia and Turkey, will also benefit. The 
investment program, among its indirect benefits, will (i) improve road network management, and 
(ii)  increase  business  activities  and  jobs  with  forward  or  backward  linkages  to  road  network 
development. 
 
53. 
The  construction,  under  Tranches  1  and  2,  of  the  two  bypass  roads  along  the  Black 
Sea—(i) from Choloki to Makhinjuari skirting Kobuleti, and (ii) from Makhinjuari to Sarpi skirting 
Batumi—is expected to divert substantial traffic from the existing Poti–Batumi–Sarpi road. The 
existing  road,  which  runs  through  the  urban  areas  of  Batumi  and  Kobuleti,  is  congested, 
accident-prone,  and  in  poor  condition.  Traffic  diverted  to  the  bypass  roads  will  benefit  from 
faster transit on a smoother driving surface with better vertical and horizontal alignment and less 
congestion.  Traffic  that  continues  to  use  the  existing  road  will  also  benefit  from  a  reduction  in 
the volume of traffic and, therefore, in congestion. The projects will directly benefit road users, 
road construction companies, traders, and other people who derive income from improved road 
traffic  and  trade  in  Georgia.  But,  in  the  longer  term,  the  bypass  roads will  benefit  the  regional 
economy  of  the  Autonomous  Republic  of  Adjara,  where  the  major  industries  are  tourism  and 
citrus fruit exports. Better transport is a key factor in the further development of those industries. 
The  present  Poti–Batumi–Sarpi  road  is  an  integral  transit  corridor  in  Georgia,  connecting 
Azerbaijan,  Armenia,  and  the  Central  Asian  countries  with  Turkey.  These  countries  will  also 
benefit from more-efficient movement of transit traffic because of the bypass roads.

road  map  and  the  investment  program,  and  (v)  adequate  financing.  The  program  also  needs

caused  by  inadequate  design  and  preconstruction  works.  The  investment  program  needs 
coordinated investments in the neighboring countries. The Government has taken the necessary 
measures to minimize these risks. MORDI and the Ministry of Finance will coordinate the work 
of the agencies so that execution issues are resolved promptly. The Government is committed 
to enforcing axle-load controls and further increasing funding for road maintenance. ADB, with 
its partners, will provide sustained support to the Roads Department to strengthen its capacity to 
manage  the  road  network.  Adequate  consulting  services  will  be  provided  to  help  the  Roads 
Department  prepare  subsequent  projects,  manage  implementation,  monitor  performance,

A. 

Transport Sector Overview   

Georgia  borders  Armenia,  Azerbaijan,  the  Russian  Federation,  and  Turkey  and  is  the 
1. 
lynchpin in the Europe–Caucasus–Asia transport network. It is a small country, to the south of 
the  main  Caucasus  mountain  range,  with  a  population  of  4.4  million.  After  independence  in 
1991, output declined by 70%, with the loss of Soviet markets, the end of large budget transfers 
from  Moscow,  and  the  impact  of  civil  war  and  ethnic  conflicts,  which  displaced  some  300,000 
people. By 2000, recorded gross domestic product (GDP) was only 30%–35% of its 1989 level, 
although  there  is  a  (large)  shadow  economy,  estimated  to  be  up  to  33%  of  GDP.  Per  capita 
income is at the lower end of the scale for lower-middle-income countries. 
 
2. 
Georgia enjoys a strategic location it has yet to fully capitalize on.  It is on the shortest 
route  from  Europe  to  Azerbaijan,  Armenia,  and  the  Central  Asian  countries  through  its  Black 
Sea  ports,  Poti  and  Batumi.  It  can  also  link  the  Russian  Federation  and  Turkey.  Its  physical 
location makes Georgia a key transport link on the most direct route from the Black Sea to the 
Caspian  Sea  and  Central  Asia—the  historic  Silk  Road,  which  the  current  Transport  Corridor 
Europe–Caucasus–Asia  (TRACECA)  initiative  seeks  to  emulate.  Trade  with  neighboring 
countries, both transit and bilateral, is thus an important feature of the economy. Georgia is also 
developing closer economic cooperation with Azerbaijan and Turkey.  
 
3. 
Poor  infrastructure  and  cumbersome  processes  inhibit  the  full  exploitation  of  transit 
economy potential. Traffic flows from the Caspian Sea, primarily crude oil and oil products, are 
rapidly expanding. The main flow in the corridor is unidirectional, consisting primarily of oil and 
oil  products,  moving  west  to  Poti  and  Batumi.  Non-oil  traffic  mostly  comprises  Armenian  and 
Azeri  trade  goods,  which  account  for  a  significant  share  of  the  turnover  of  Georgia’s  ports. 
Georgia  has  not  yet  been  able  to  realize  the  transit  potential  from  Central  Asian  countries. 
Designed  at  a  time  of  much-higher  traffic,  the  transport  infrastructure  can  handle  significant 
additional  traffic  growth  with  limited  new  construction,  although  the  aging  rail,  road,  and  port 
infrastructure  requires  significant  investments  to  rehabilitate  and  modernize,  after  years  of 
maintenance  neglect.  Despite  being  the  closest  maritime  gateway  to  nearly  all  Central  Asian 
countries, the Georgian route now accounts for a negligible portion of the foreign trade of these 
countries. Long transit times, poor road conditions, the multiple borders to be crossed, and the 
number of times cargoes need to be handled, together with formal and informal payments and 
delays,  explain  the  limited  use  of  the  Caucasus  route.  The  significant  reduction  in  corruption 
should improve Georgia’s transit competitiveness. 
 
4. 
Limited  transport  infrastructure  adds  to  the  cost  of  doing  business  and  leaves  much  of 
the  population  out  of the  national  economy.  Infrastructure constraints add  to  the  cost  of  doing 
business,  deter  foreign  investment,  add  time  and  costs  to  the  transit  corridor,  and  leave  large 
segments  of  the  population  out  of  mainstream  economic  activities.  Analyses  show  a  close 
correlation  between  poverty  in  rural  households  and  the  extent  to  which  the  households  are 
linked  to  markets.  Poor  transport  infrastructure  partly  explains  why  almost  two-thirds  of  rural 
household agricultural production is for self-subsistence and about 20% of rural households do 
not trade at all. A World Bank rural infrastructure survey revealed that only in 5% of surveyed 
communities were roads repaired within the last 5 years, while in 41% of communities they were 
last  repaired  over  15  years  ago.  Poor  connectivity  has  also  contributed  to  weak  linkages

The  Government’s  transport  strategy  is  to  support  market  integration,  to  develop  the

environmental  concerns;  (ii)  strengthening  institutions  to  fulfill  their  policy-making,  monitoring,

authorities  acquire  the  technical  and  financial  resources  necessary  to  deal  with  their  new 
obligations;  (iv)  ensuring  capabilities  for  efficient  road  management,  based  on  modern 
information systems; and (v) capitalizing on the benefits of a transit economy, and the ability to 
compete  with  alternative  routes,  requiring  a  concerted  public–private  effort  to  design  and 
implement a vision that significantly transcends the transport sector.

2009.

G. 

Road Safety 

27. 
Road  safety  needs  serious  attention;  there  has  been  a  sharp  rise  in  traffic  accidents, 
fatalities, and injuries. The current fatality rate is much higher in Georgia than in other European 
countries,  and  the  economic  and  human  losses  have  been  significant.  While  traffic  accidents 
have  many  causes,  he  inadequate  road  network  is  a  factor.  Curves  and  superelevation  are 
inappropriately  designed  on  many  roads,  and  safety  furniture  is  lacking.  Other  causes  of 
accidents  are  weak  enforcement  of  safety  regulations,  reckless  driving,  and  the  larger  vehicle 
fleet. The Government should take remedial action to curb accidents. 
 
28. 
The  more  than  6,000  accidents in 2008  that  involved  death  or  serious  injury  and killed 
867 people represented an increase of more than 18% over the 2007 figure (Table A2.6). The 
fatality  rate  relative  to  the  vehicle  fleet,  at  12  per  10,000  vehicles  in  2008,  is  high  (removing 
scrapped vehicles from the fleet statistics would result in an even-higher rate)—and far exceeds 
the rate in other European countries.2 Both fatalities and serious injuries are on the rise. Road 
safety is therefore a serious social concern.  
 
29. 
Georgia, as a member of the European Conference of Ministers of Transport (ECMT), is 
committed to reducing road deaths by 50% by 2012, compared with the 2000 figure. Whereas 
other  countries  had  made  good  progress  by  2004,  with  Western  European  countries  reducing 
deaths by 5.2% per year and Central and Eastern European countries by 3.3% per year, road 
deaths  in  Georgia  increased  by  6.4%  a  year  over  the  period.  Besides  emotional  pain,  traffic 
accidents have a direct impact on economic growth. A 1999 World Bank working paper, Road 
Safety  in  Individual  ECA  Countries,3 suggested  that  the  socioeconomic  cost  of  road  accidents 
for Georgia was about 1.1% of GDP. Estimates made in 2007 indicate that the annual economic 
loss is now at least $100 million, 1.4% of GDP.

H. 

Vehicle Axle-Load Control 

32. 
Georgia  has  regulations  that  limit  vehicle  axle  load  to  11.5  tons  (European  Union 
standard),  but  lower  than  the  13.0  tons  in  neighboring  countries.  But  enforcement  is  weak, 
primarily  because  of  limited  institutional  capacity  and  lack  of  vehicle  weighing  facilities  along 
main roads. As a result, vehicle axle overloading is prevalent. On the other hand, if enforcement 
were  high,  there  would  dealing  with  transit  traffic  from  countries  with  higher  limits  would  be  a 
problem.  The  countries  in  the  Caucasus  countries  must  coordinate  and  agree  on  a  common 
limit. 
 
33. 
Informal surveys conducted during the preparation of project 1 under the MFF indicated 
a problem with trucks exceeding the axle-load limit. Heavy vehicle weights are a primary cause 
of rapid pavement deterioration; therefore, vehicle axle-load control must be enforced to prevent 
such premature deterioration. 
 
Vehicle  weigh  stations  must  be  established  along  international  roads,  and  overloaded 
34. 
vehicles should be required to redistribute or unload excess freight and also to collect reliable 
data on vehicle axle loads by installing permanent “weigh-in-motion” devices at key points. ADB 
is proposing to establish a vehicle weigh station on the Kobuleti bypass, under Tranche 1 of the 
MFF.

Road Transport Services 

35.  Georgia’s  road  freight  industry  is  made  up  of  private  companies  and  is  unregulated. 
Entry into the market is easy. It is difficult to judge the extent of market efficiency, but the freight 
rates of GEL0.20–GEL0.27 per ton-km for hauls of 100–500 km are consistent with the Highway 
Development  and  Management-4  estimate  of  operating  costs,  which  suggests  that  profits  are 
not excessive. 

36. 
Intercity bus services are extensive and frequent. Although most routes are plied by both 
minibuses and larger buses, there is little to choose in terms of journey time, as all buses will 
stop  to  pick  up  passengers  en  route  if  they  have  room.  Fares  between  bus  stations  (e.g., 
between  Tbilisi  and  Batumi)  are  controlled  by  bus  station  operators,  who  take  a  cut  from  the 
fare. Bus station operators also appear to control capacity—a new entrant would find it difficult 
to operate a new service from an existing bus station. This control of both prices and capacity 
may be hindering the development of new services (e.g., express services).

Russian  Federation  and  Turkey.  The  physical  location  of  Georgia  ensures  that  it  is  a  key

multi-road  corridors  will  diversify  the  connectivity  of  Georgia  to  neighboring  countries  and 
reduce  the  cost  of  subregional  and  international  transport,  benefiting  both  the  local  economy

links. The subregional multi-road-corridors also serve as principal domestic corridors linking the 
major  cities,  ports  and  tourist  centers,  and  their  development  enhances  economic  growth 
through more efficient passenger and freight transport.

4. 
Structures  and  tunnels. There will be (i) 18 bridges (2,984 m in total length) and one 
tunnel (400 m) along the Kobuleti bypass; and (ii) 19 bridges (3,799 m) and 5 tunnels (1,510 m) 
along the Batumi bypass. Six bridges will be 500 meters or more in length.  
 
5. 
The  structures  and  tunnels  conform  to  Georgian  specifications  except  as  mentioned  in 
para.  2(i).  Bridges  are  designed  to  carry  80-ton  loads  with  100  years’  flood  return  frequency. 
Culverts are designed to carry 50 years’ flood return frequency, and side drains, 20 years’ flood 
return frequency.  
 
The project road is located in seismic zone IV (modified Mercalli scale); its design must 
6. 
therefore include anti-seismic measures to be included in the design of structures. Most bridges 
will be simple span reinforced concrete on piers and spread footings. Some bridges with longer 
spans will be pre-stressed T-girder superstructure. 
 
7. 
The  Georgian  standard  for  two-way  tunnels  has  a  2.5  m  wide  emergency  lane  on  one 
side with a clear width of the 11.5 m road. This is an overly large tunnel cross-section compared 
with  most  international  standards  and  would  create  difficulty  in  construction  on  poor  ground, 
besides  increasing  construction  time  and  cost.  An  internationally  accepted  cross-section,  with 
two  lanes  3.5  m  wide,  shoulders  1.25  m  wide,  and  an  inspection  walkway  0.9 m  wide  on  one 
side,  is  recommended.  The  tunnel  is  about  11  m  wide,  and  about  7.5  m  high.  No  tunnel 
ventilation is believed to be required because of the low traffic volume and the relatively short 
length of the tunnels. An illumination system is included in the tunnel design. Suitable facilities 
for traffic safety and emergency, based on the length of the tunnels and traffic volume, are also 
included in the design and in the cost estimates.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF TRANCHE 1 AND 2 PROJECTS  

A. 

General 

The economic analysis assessed the construction of bypass roads on the Poti–Batumi–
1. 
Sarpi Road in the Autonomous Republic of Adjara. The projects comprise (i) the construction of 
a  34  kilometer  (km)  two- and  four-lane  bypass  road  from  Kobuleti  to  Makhinjuari  detouring 
Kobuleti,  and  (ii)  the  construction  of  a  14  km  two-lane  bypass  road  from  Makhinjuari  to  Sarpi 
detouring Batumi. The projects will divert transit traffic away from the existing Poti–Batumi–Sarpi 
Road,  which  runs  through  the  urban  areas  of  Kobuleti  and  Batumi.  The  existing  road  is 
congested,  accident-prone,  and  in  poor  condition.  The  economic  analysis  covered  the  period 
2010–2033, with the projects having their first full year of operation in 2014. The analysis was 
based on a comparison of with- and without-project cases and used economic prices in the first 
quarter  of  2009  unless  otherwise  indicated.  Various  alternatives  for  diverting  cross-border 
through  traffic  from  the  existing  main  roads  in  Kobuleti  and  Batumi  were  investigated.  They 
included expanding the existing in-city roads and constructing new ones. Both alternatives were 
found to be economically and socially unviable because of their huge resettlement impact. For 
the bypass roads, after several alignments were compared in terms of their environmental and 
social impact, the proposed alignment was determined to be the least-cost option.

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The project, under the Subregional Roads Corridors Development Investment Program, can be linked indirectly to the overall 
objective of the Government’s Development Agenda as reflected in the Basic Data and Directions 2008–2011 document and 
ADB’s  interim  operational  strategy  2008–2009.  Poverty  reduction  is  one  of  the  priorities  of  the  Government.  The  main 
objectives are to reduce, over 2006–2015, overall poverty incidence from 31% to 15% and extreme poverty from 11% to 4%. 
These  objectives  can  be  achieved  through  infrastructure  development,  which  removes  economic  growth  bottlenecks.  An 
important  strategy  in  this  regard  is  to  develop  transport  infrastructure  to  strengthen  market  access  and  to  realize  Georgia’s 
transit economy potential more fully. ADB’s priorities in its interim operational strategy are based on such considerations as (i) 
alignment with the Government’s development agenda; (ii) selectivity in directing limited resources at a few priority areas; and 
(iii) complementarities  with  other  development  partners.  The  strategy  will  promote  sustainable  economic  growth,  with 
governance,  regional  cooperation,  and  environmental  protection  as  pervasive  themes,  by  (i)  improving  municipal 
infrastructure services within the evolving decentralization process, (ii) reducing road transportation constraints on economic 
activity,  and  (iii)  upgrading  and  developing  energy  infrastructure.  ADB’s  operational  engagement  in  this  area  will  involve 
financing  improvements  in  the  highway  network,  resulting  in  lower  transport  costs,  better  road  safety,  and  reduced  traffic 
congestion  and  vehicle  pollution.  These  are  high-return,  in-demand  operations,  and  the  Government  has  requested  ADB 
assistance in this area to help address some of the remaining investment gaps. 
 
Georgia’s road network consists of 1,495 kilometers (km) of international, 5,446 km of state, and 13,386 km of local roads. 
The country has five main roads and highways, including the east–west highway connecting the ports of Poti and Batumi to 
the  Azerbaijan  border.  The  Government  has  been  encouraging  private  sector  participation  in  the  construction  and 
maintenance of highways. Given the country’s location, transport sector development is critical in reducing the logistics costs 
of  economic  activity  and  realizing  Georgia’s  full  potential  as  a  transit  economy.  The  difficult  terrain  in  some  sections  and 
congestion  slow  traffic,  increase  vehicle  operating  costs,  and  reduce  road  safety.  Road  maintenance  costs  are  also  high 
because of the terrain and weather conditions. About 10% of the main roads, 30% of the secondary roads, and 50% of the 
local  roads  are  in  poor  condition  and  need  rehabilitation.  The  Government  has  prioritized  the  improvement  of  the  road 
network. The link between access to infrastructure services and poverty incidence has been well established in cross-country 
studies. For Georgia, rural–urban differences in access to infrastructure services go some way toward explaining the pattern 
of  poverty  incidence.  Because  of  the  generally  poor  condition  of  secondary  and  local  roads,  Georgia’s  rural  population, 
including  ethnic  minorities  living  in  southern  Georgia,  face  problems  of  isolation,  with  inadequate  access  to  markets  and  to 
social  services.  In  rehabilitating  and  upgrading  secondary  and  local  roads,  it  will  be  important  to  build  in  participatiory 
mechanisms involving local communities in the design and maintenance of the roads. Therefore, the project will have indirect 
linkage to the overall development goal. 

B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:  General Intervention 
1. Key Issues  
Georgia ranks 97th out of 177 countries on the human development index of the United Nations Development Programme. It 
ranks  higher  than  Azerbaijan  (99th)  but  lower  than  Armenia  (79th).  Although  growth  will  need  to  be  more  broad based  to

one-third  of  Georgia’s  population  is  below  the  national  poverty  line  and  the  poverty  is  relatively  higher  in  the  rural  areas. 
Poverty incidence in Georgia is close to that in other countries in the South Caucasus. The incidence of poverty in Georgia is

transport services provide intermediate inputs. The proposed project will have both short-term and long-term positive impact.

entitlement, and resettlement management adopted for the project will be made available in the 
local  language(s)  and  distributed  to  affected  persons.  Each  affected  person  will  be  provided 
information regarding specific entitlements. Information sharing on LAR entitlement was shared 
at the village level through consultation and through formal public consultation during the public 
hearing under the environmental impact assessment in the month of June 2009. This summary 
LARP will be translated into the local language (Georgian) and disclosed to affected persons at 
the local level. A copy of the LARP will be available at the  Roads Department. The same will be 
available for the affected persons as and when asked for. A copy of the LARP will be disclosed 
on ADB’s website. 

I. 

Resettlement Budget, Financing and Implementation Schedule 

10. 
The resettlement cost estimate for project 1 components includes eligible compensation, 
resettlement  assistance,  and  support  for  the  costs  of  resettlement  plan  implementation.  All 
LARP  preparation  and  implementation  costs,  including  the  cost  of  compensation  and  land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  administration,  will  be  considered  an  integral  part  of  project  cost 
and will be contributed as a counterpart fund by the Georgia Government, in particular Roads 
Department. The total estimated cost for the LARP for project 1 is about $5.90 million. Roads 
Department is responsible for the timely allocation of the funds needed to implement the LARP. 
As  per  the  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  fund  flow,  the  budget  for  compensation  and 
rehabilitation  will  be  directly  disbursed  by  Roads  Department  to  the  affected  person.  All  land 
acquisition, resettlement, and compensation will be completed before the start of civil works.  

J. 

Monitoring and Evaluation  

11. 
Land acquisition and resettlement tasks under the project will be monitored. Monitoring 
will be the responsibility of Roads Department. Internal monitoring will be carried out routinely 
by  DRD  and/or  Roads  Department.  The  results  will  be  communicated  to  ADB  through  the 
quarterly  project  implementation  reports.  External  monitoring  will  be  carried  out  twice  a  year, 
and its results communicated to DRD and/or Roads Department and ADB through semiannual 
reports.  The  Roads  Department  will  carry  out  a  post-implementation  evaluation  of  the  LARP 
about a year after the completion of its implementation. Roads Department may need external 
help in monitoring the first-tranche LARP implementation activities.
